discussion.content:
Fully agree with Romail link, 
Here is the clue to answer this triky question: "...A four-way handshake is used to establish another key called the Pairwise Transient Key (PTK)..."

questions.answer_description:
The authentication process leaves two considerations: the access point (AP) still needs to authenticate itself to the client station (STA), and keys to encrypt the traffic need to be derived. The earlier EAP exchange or WPA2-PSK configuration has provided the shared secret key PMK (Pairwise Master Key). To derive the
PMK from the WPA-PSK, the PSK is put through PBKDF2-SHA1 as the cryptographic hash function. This key is, however, designed to last the entire session and should be exposed as little as possible. Therefore the four-way handshake is used to establish another key called the PTK (Pairwise Transient Key). The PTK is generated by concatenating the following attributes: PMK, AP nonce (ANonce), STA nonce (SNonce), AP MAC address, and STA MAC address. The product is then put through a pseudo random function. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_802.11i-2004
questions.question_text: Which key is established using the four-way handshake during the WPA authentication process?

questions.answer_description: Regardless of whether WPA or WPA2 is used during the initial connection between the station and the AP, the two agree on common security requirements.
questions.question_text: When the enterprise-based authentication method is used for WPA2, a bidirectional handshake exchange occurs between the client and the authenticator. Which five options are results of that exchange being used on a controller-based network? (Choose five.)

choices.B: binding of a Pairwise Master Key at the client and the controller
choices.C: creation of the Pairwise Transient Key
choices.A: a bidirectional exchange of a nonce used for key generation
choices.D: distribution of the Group Transient Key
choices.F: proof that each side is alive
choices.E: distribution of the Pairwise Master key for caching at the access point

discussion.content:
Here is a big clue for this question:
The entire point of the process is so authentication can occur without exposing the pairwise master key. So distributing it would defeat the purpose of the handshake.

Answer D has a typo.
It is called the Group Temporal Key, not Group Transient Key.

MUST BE B - ETSI.

A = wrong - this is a Canadian agency
C = wrong - IEEE is standards agency, NOT regulatory agency
D = wrong - NTT is telecom provider

per the CISCO study guide : 
"
In Europe and several other countries, the European Telecommunication Standards Institute
(ETSI; http://www.etsi.org) regulates radio transmitter use...
"

NOTE : Asia is contained within "several other countries"

I do not think there is any correct answer provided for this question.

NTT is a telecom provider in Asia, not a regulatory body.
The question is also not specific enough. There are multiple regulatory bodies within Asia for different regions. For example, in Japan the regulatory body would be MIC, but for China it would be MII.

questions.question_text: An engineer needs to find out the maximum EIRP allowed for their office in Asia. What regulatory body should be contacted?

choices.C: only the syslog severity level number of error and greater
choices.D: only the syslog severity level number of error and less

discussion.content:
it sounds so illogical...
code-value and severity conepts are mixed-up

The messages of the following severity levels will be sent
• emergencies = Severity level 0
• alerts = Severity level 1
• critical = Severity level 2
• errors = Severity level 3

• emergencies = Severity level 0
• alerts = Severity level 1
• critical = Severity level 2
• errors = Severity level 3
• warnings = Severity level 4
• notifications = Severity level 5
• informational = Severity level 6
• debugging = Severity level 7

D is correct but the Explanation is wrong.
If you set a syslog level, only those messages whose severity is equal to or less than that level are sent to the syslog servers.

questions.answer_description: Here the syslog level is set to errors, so it will send all logs with a severity level of errors, as well as all other messages with a greater severity level.

comments.content: also agree with xtrattitude4u, 5.725 is a border not a freq, so that would make ALL answers (C/D) WRONG.... right ?

discussion.content:
Fully agree to xtrattitude4u,

- UNII-2 extend ranges from 5.470 to 5.725 Ghz (11 channels).
- UNII-3 ranges from 5.725 to 5.825 Ghz (4 channels).

Therefore C and D are both valids.

This question is difficult to answer because 5.725ghz is not a valid band. It acts as the border between UNII-2 extended and UNII-3, so either answer could be correct.


U-NII-2-Extended: 5.470–5.725 GHz
U-NII-3: 5.725-5.850 GHz

questions.question_text: A wireless engineer has an access point using the 5.725-GHz channel in the United States. In which band is the AP operating?
